cluster.title: Hillary Clinton testifies before House Oversight panel on Jeffrey Epstein investigation.

synthesis.narrative:
## State of the Story: Hillary Clinton's Epstein Deposition

### Key Facts Established

Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton testified before the House Oversight Committee on Thursday, February 26, 2026, regarding the Jeffrey Epstein investigation in what marks the first time a former first couple has appeared before a congressional panel under subpoena [1]. The closed-door deposition took place at the Chappaqua Performing Arts Center near the Clintons' home in New York [3][5] and lasted approximately six hours, concluding around 5:30 p.m. ET [8].

Clinton maintained her position that she has no knowledge that would assist the investigation, stating in her opening remarks: "I do not recall ever encountering Mr. Epstein. I never flew on his plane or visited his island homes or offices" [7]. She told lawmakers she met Ghislaine Maxwell only "a few times" [1] and that her name does not appear in the Justice Department's publicly released Epstein files [1].

### Timeline of Events

The deposition followed months of legal wrangling between the Clintons and House Republicans, with the couple initially resisting the subpoena and facing threats of contempt of Congress charges [1][3]. Clinton had previously provided a sworn declaration to the committee on January 13, 2026, stating she had no knowledge of crimes committed by Epstein and Maxwell [5].

The proceedings were temporarily disrupted when Rep. Lauren Boebert (R-Colo.) shared unauthorized photos of Clinton during the closed-door testimony with conservative influencer Benny Johnson [3][5][10]. The session was paused while Clinton's legal team protested the breach of House rules [5][10], with Democrats calling the action "completely against the rules" [10].

### Political Tensions and Accusations

Clinton delivered a scathing opening statement accusing Republicans of conducting "partisan political theatre" and a "fishing expedition" designed to "distract attention from President Trump's actions and to cover them up" [3][5]. She argued that if the committee was serious about the investigation, it would question Trump directly under oath about "the tens of thousands of times he shows up in the Epstein files" [3][10].

Committee Chairman James Comer (R-Ky.) defended the proceedings, stating "no one's accusing the Clintons of any wrongdoing" but emphasizing that "the American people have a lot of questions" [1][7]. He described the deposition as "productive" and said "we learned a lot," though noted that Clinton frequently referred questions about the Clinton Global Initiative to her husband [8][10].

### Upcoming Developments

Former President Bill Clinton is scheduled to testify on Friday, February 27, 2026, which will mark the first time a former president has testified before a congressional panel in over 40 years [1]. Comer indicated this deposition is expected to be "even longer" than Hillary Clinton's [8][10]. The committee plans to release video of Hillary Clinton's deposition within 24 hours, with the transcript to follow after review by Clinton's lawyers [8].

deepAnalysis.historicalContext: This investigation represents a continuation of long-standing political battles between the Clintons and Republicans dating back to the 1990s Whitewater investigations and impeachment proceedings. The Epstein case has become a political weapon for both parties since his 2019 death, with each side attempting to implicate the other's prominent figures. The last time a former president testified before Congress was Gerald Ford in 1983 regarding his pardon of Richard Nixon, making Bill Clinton's upcoming testimony historically significant. The closed-door format and subpoena power echo previous high-stakes congressional investigations like Benghazi and the January 6th committee, reflecting the increasingly partisan nature of congressional oversight in the modern era.
implications: Sets precedent for congressional subpoena power over former high-ranking officials
Escalates political weaponization of the Epstein case ahead of 2026 midterms
Tests boundaries of executive privilege and congressional oversight authority
May influence public perception of both Clinton and Trump political legacies
Could impact future congressional investigation procedures and decorum
Demonstrates ongoing challenges in maintaining bipartisan oversight functions
May affect Democratic Party's 2026 and 2028 electoral strategies
Could set stage for reciprocal investigations if party control changes
